result.title: Your IQ Estimate
result.lookup_hint: Paste your ID to open your detailed report.
result.disclaimer_iq: Your result reflects performance across five cognitive domains: reasoning, math, verbal, spatial, and memory. It is scored using a normalized model with mean = 100 and standard deviation = 15. Scores are indicative, not diagnostic.
result.iq_explainer_short: Your IQ estimate (mean = 100, SD = 15) is plotted on a normal curve. Most people fall between 85 – 115. Shaded regions indicate standard ability ranges used in research and education.
result.explainer_long: Scores are derived from your accuracy across multiple cognitive domains. Each correct answer contributes to a weighted z-score that is scaled to the population mean (μ = 100, σ = 15). The 95% confidence interval (CI) reflects normal statistical variation based on test length.
result.explanation_method: The scoring model follows widely accepted psychometric conventions similar to those used in standardized ability assessments (e.g., WAIS and Raven matrices). Z-scores across categories are averaged and rescaled to fit the IQ metric.
result.references: References: Condon & Revelle (2014), Wechsler (2008), and other open psychometric frameworks.
result.iq_curve_caption: The curve below shows how your estimated IQ compares to the general population.

about.title: About this test
about.method: This test uses a balanced mix of open-format cognitive tasks modeled after well-established reasoning and aptitude assessments. It estimates general reasoning ability (g) in a transparent and research-oriented way.
about.audience: Suitable for ages 14 and up. Designed for education, personal insight, or preliminary aptitude screening. No personal data is collected — only an anonymous ID is stored for comparison over time.
about.limitations: Results are approximate and can vary with factors such as focus, language, and environment. This tool is educational and not a substitute for a formal psychological evaluation.

iq_explainer.title: How your IQ estimate is calculated
iq_explainer.intro: This assessment uses a research-based method to estimate general cognitive ability (g). It combines multiple domains to produce a standardized IQ-like score for educational and self-reflection purposes.

method.heading: Calculation method
method.p1: Each correct answer contributes to your raw accuracy. Scores are weighted across five domains: Reasoning, Math, Verbal, Spatial, and Memory.
method.p2: Your total is converted into a standardized score using a z-score transformation, then scaled to an IQ-equivalent metric (mean = 100, SD = 15).
method.p3: A 95% confidence interval (CI) indicates expected variation based on the number of questions and category balance.

theory.heading: Psychometric background
theory.p1: The scoring model follows classical test theory (CTT) principles and psychometric scaling used in validated aptitude and intelligence measures.
theory.p2: It reflects conventions used in instruments such as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale (WAIS-IV) and Raven’s Progressive Matrices, adjusted for open-source testing contexts.

audience.heading: Intended use
audience.p1: This test provides a general, research-style IQ estimate that can be used for self-assessment, education, or personal development.
audience.p2: It does not define intelligence but provides a snapshot of cognitive processing and reasoning efficiency.

limitations.heading: Interpretation and limitations
limitations.p1: Results depend on focus, motivation, and familiarity with similar problem types. Re-taking the test may slightly improve scores due to practice effects.
limitations.p2: This test is anonymous, educational, and non-diagnostic. It should not be used for hiring or clinical decisions.

iq_explainer.summary: In short: this test provides a transparent, research-inspired estimate of general cognitive ability — standardized to the IQ scale (mean 100, SD 15) for intuitive interpretation.
